summary:
Dr. Andrew Wilkinson is an Australian research scientist with a background in immunology and cancer therapeutics. He completed his PhD in 2019 at the University of Queensland under Prof. Geoffrey Hill on transplant immunology and has experience in multiple diseases models (Myeloma, T1D, Leukemia, GVHD, Ovarian Cancer) and techniques (Phase I/II & III clinical trials & respective disease models). He has published in reputible journals (most recently in Blood) and presented at international (AAI) and national meetings (TSANZ, Immunotherapies, ASI). 

Specialties:
•	Problem solving and creative solutions
•	Driving individual projects with succinct reporting and collaboration
•	Highly experienced in flow cytometry and its analysis 
•	Broad knowledge of laboratory techniques and scientific writing

Unique Australian Skills: Losing boomerangs, getting sun-burnt, not surfing well

Unique COVID skills: Successful immigration during a pandemic, already had a webcam and computer at home, holding my breath for long periods of time when people come within 1.5 meters

treasury_media.title: In This Issue
treasury_media.description: The shared gp130 component is the receptor signal transduction subunit for the IL-6 family of cytokines. In classical signaling, IL-6 binding to membrane-bound IL-6Rα (mIL-6Rα) induces gp130 homodimerization, whereas trans signaling involves...

Granulocytes Are Unresponsive to IL-6 Due to an Absence of gp130

profile_positions.description:
I work as a postdoctoral research fellow specializing in immunology at the multidisciplinary Cancer Therapeutics team led by Dr. Sherry Wu at the School of Biomedical Science (UQ, Australia). I am developing combinational immunotherapies for ovarian cancer and pairing them with targeted, novel miRNA approaches delivered via nanoparticles.
•	Responsible for driving individual projects focusing on reactivating anti-tumour immunity in ovarian cancer through targeted microRNA therapies and combinational immunotherapies
o	Targeted miRNA therapy, in situ dendritic cell vaccines, chemotherapy, checkpoint inhibition (PD-1/PD-L1, CTLA-4)
•	Assay and protocol development (SOP); designed and led group immunology experiments
•	Co-supervised students (PhD & undergraduate) and taught other lab members immunology and lab techniques
•	Assays used: Dissection and organ preparation, flow cytometry (14-colour panel design), analysis (FACS DIVA, FlowJo, Prism, statistics), cell culture, imaging (IVIS, Fluorescent microscopy)
•	Molecular techniques: bacterial/plasmid work, cell line transductions, RT-qPCR, Western blot, RNA isolation from tumour tissue.
•	Advanced programs used: FlowJo, FACSDiva, Prism (Biostatistics), Living Image, QuantStudio
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description:
In my PhD I worked on understanding the role of IL-6 signaling in Graft-Versus-Host Disease (GVHD) following allogeneic stem cell transplantation (alloSCT). My project followed a successful Phase I/II trial of IL-6 inhibition (tocilizumab) for acute GVHD and focused on investigating the mechanisms behind the therapy by using clinical samples from our ongoing Phase III trial and preclinical murine models. This research was conducted in the Bone Marrow Transplantation Laboratory under Prof. Geoffrey Hill at QIMR Berghofer (Australia).
•	Supervisors: Prof. Geoffrey Hill, Assoc. Prof. Kate Gartlan, and Dr. Slavica Vuckovic
•	Understanding the impact of IL-6 and its signaling pathways on GVHD severity, graft-versus-leukemia, and its effect on myeloid and T cell differentiation in preclinical murine models
•	Immunomonitoring of myeloid and T cell subsets following IL-6 inhibition in alloSCT patients from our phase III clinical trial utilizing whole blood ex vivo assays
o	Followed strict clinical trial procedures for safe sample handling and clinical data storage and analysis
•	Assays used: Flow Cytometry (14-colour), Intracellular cytokine staining (ICCS), ELISA, Cytokine bead array (CBA), cell culture, RT-qPCR, Western Blotting, Imaging (IVIS, H&E, Fluorescent microscopy; Amnis image stream)
•	Advanced programs used: FlowJo, FACSDiva, Prism (Biostatistics), Living Image
•	Scientific oral presentations of my work at local (BIG, QIMR, TRI), national (ASI, Immunotherapy), and international (AAI, TSANZ) conferences
•	Keywords: Clinical immunology/Cell biology/Transplantation/Cancer therapeutics/Hematology/IL-6/IL-6R mAb
profile_positions.title: PhD Student

profile_positions.description: Working under Prof. Geoff Hill, I was part of a team investigating cytokine dysregulation following allogeneic stem cell transplantation and the clinical impact of its inhibition. I helped process and analyze clinical samples from the Phase III clinical trial (prophylatic inhibition of IL-6 (Tocilizumab) for acute graft-versus-host-disease following allogeneic stem cell transplantation). I also worked on the setting up and and the immunological analysis of preclinical models of acute graft-versus-host-disease.
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant

profile_positions.description:
Under Dr. Rebecca Prue & Prof. Farzin Farzaneh, I worked on processing and analyzing samples from two concurrent Roche Clinical drug Trials for Lung and Prostate Cancer. 
•	Processing of clinical patient blood samples for immunophenotyping (including ex vivo degranulation assays) to show mechanisms of drug action
•	Flow cytometry analysis (FlowJo) of clinical data 
•	Collation and verifying the integrity of large data sets
profile_positions.title: Clinical Research Assistant

profile_positions.description:
At MMRI I worked under Dr. Slavica Vuckovic on Multiple Myeloma using a special humanized mouse model that was generated through human progenitor stem cells isolated from cord bloods from the Mater Mother's hospital. A year later my work was combined with Assoc. Prof. Kristen Radford's Cancer Immunotherapy team, where I helped develop the humanized mouse model to study rare cross-presenting dendritic cell subsets for targeted cancer vaccines.
•	Determining the blood immune profile that correlates with the development of type 1 diabetes in children by immunomonitoring and comparing with their siblings/twins (who often do not develop diabetes but share similar environmental and/or genetic conditions) 
•	Cell banking; optimized the isolation and freezing protocol of CD34+ progenitor cells from donor cord bloods. These were used to seed humanized mouse model (NOD/SCID)
•	Investigating chemotherapies and novel drug treatments on multiple myeloma in our humanized mouse model. Analyzing impact on tumor burden and activation of anti-tumor immunity
•	Immunophenotyping of humanized mice following generation and treatment with FLT3L to expand rare dendritic cell subsets
    o	Characterization of their phenotype – Flow Cytometry, cross-presentation in vitro assays, co-  stimulatory and pattern recognition receptor expression (Flow, PCR)
•	Assays/techniques used: Whole blood assays, immunomonitoring of drug treatments in mice, tissue culture, flow cytometry, PCR, western blots, manuscript preparation, biostatistics, patient data management and filing (consent forms)
profile_positions.title: Research Assistant
